subsection.title: Volume and Surface Area
subsection.p: In Section 5.1 we used exponents to calculate the area of a square and the volume of a cube.

ul.li: Volume is the amount of space contained within a three-dimensional object. It is measured in cubic units, such as cubic feet or cubic centimeters.
Surface area is the sum of the areas of all the faces or surfaces that contain a solid. It is measured in square units.

subsection.p: We saw that the area of a square whose side has length s units is given by A=s^2 square units, and the volume of a cube of side s units is gven by V=s^3 cubic units. Many other useful formulas involve exponents. The figure below shows several solid objects, along with formulas for their volumes and surface areas.

subsection.title: Solving Equations with x^2
subsection.p: Taking a square root is the opposite of squaring a number. Thus, we can undo the squaring operation by taking square roots. For example, to solve the equation x^2=64 we take the square root of each side. Saying that x^2 equals 64 is the same as saying that x is a square root of 64. Remember that every positive number has two square roots, so we write x^2 \amp =64 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Take square roots of both sides.}} \amp = \pm \sqrt{64} \amp= \pm 8 The equation has two solutions, 8 and -8.

subsection.title: Pythagorean Theorem
subsection.p: A triangle in which one of the angles is a right angle, or 90 \degree, is called a right triangle. The side opposite the right angle is the longest side of the triangle, and is called the hypotenuse. The other two sides of the triangle are called the legs.

If we know the lengths of any two sides of a right triangle, we can find the third side using a formula called the Pythagorean Theorem. We use the variable c for the length of the hypotenuse, and the lengths of the legs are denoted by a and b (it doesn't matter which is which).

sidebyside.p: If c stands for the length of the hypotenuse of a right triangle, and the lengths of the two legs are represented by a and b, then a^2 + b^2 = c^2

subsection.p: The Pythagorean theorem says that the square of the hypotenuse of a right triangle is equal to the sum of the squares of the two legs.

subsection.title: Solving for One Variable
subsection.p: In the formula in , the variable P occurs more than once. We substitute the value for P each time it occurs.

statement.p: If a principal of P dollars is invested at interest rate r, the formula A = P + Prt gives the amount of money in an account after t years. (The "amount," A, is the original principal plus the interest earned.) How long will it take an investment of $5000 to grow to $7000 in an account that pays 6% interest?

warning.p: To simplify the right side of the equation 7000 = 5000 + 5000(0.065)t it is not correct to add the two 5000's and write 7000 = 10,000(0.065)t. Remember that multiplication comes before addition in the order of operations.

subsection.p: If we plan to use a formula more than once with different values for the variables, it may be faster in the long run to solve for one of the variables in terms of the others. We have already done something like this when we put a linear equation into slope-intercept form: in that situation we solved for y in terms of x.
